{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2016}} {{Infobox person | name = Rosamond Pinchot | image = Rosamond Pinchot.jpg | alt = | caption = | birth_date = {{birth date|1904|10|26}} | birth_place = [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]], U.S. | death_date = {{death date and age|1938|01|24|1904|10|26}} | death_place = [[Old Brookville, New York]], U.S. | death_cause = [[Asphyxia]] due to [[carbon monoxide poisoning]] | resting_place = Milford Cemetery | nationality = American | other_names = Rosamond Pinchot Gaston | occupation = Actress, socialite | spouse = {{marriage|William Gaston|1928|1938}} | children = 2 | parents = [[Amos Pinchot]]
Gertrude Minturn Pinchot | relatives = Gifford Pinchot (brother)
[[Mary Pinchot Meyer|Mary Pinchot]] (half sister)
Antoinette Pinchot (half sister)
[[Gifford Pinchot]] (uncle) }} '''Rosamond Pinchot''' (October 26, 1904 – January 24, 1938) was an American [[socialite]], stage and film [[actress]]. ==Early life and career== Born in [[New York City]], Pinchot was the daughter of [[Amos Pinchot]], a wealthy lawyer and a key figure in the [[Progressive Party (United States, 1912)|Progressive Party]] and Gertrude Minturn Pinchot, the daughter of shipping magnate [[Robert Bowne Minturn, Jr.]]. She had a younger brother, Gifford (nicknamed Long Giff). Her uncle was Pennsylvania Governor [[Gifford Pinchot]] and her cousin was [[Edie Sedgwick]].{{harv|Gaston|2009|p=5}}{{cite news|title=THE WEDDINGS OF A DAY; Marriage of Miss Gertrude Minturn to Mr. Pinchot. The Ceremony at St. George's Church -- Many Guests Invited -- The Bride's Costume.|date=November 15, 1900|work=The New York Times}}{{harv|Gaston|2009|p=61}} The family divided their time between their home in New York City and the family estate, [[Grey Towers National Historic Site|Grey Towers]], in [[Milford, Pennsylvania]]. She graduated from [[Miss Chapin's School]].[https://ephemeralnewyork.wordpress.com/tag/miss-chapins-school-nyc/] Her parents divorced in 1918. After the divorce, Pinchot and her brother lived with their mother in her townhouse in New York City.{{harv|Gaston|2009|p=31}} In 1919, Amos Pinchot married magazine writer [[Ruth Pickering Pinchot|Ruth Pickering]] with whom he would have two more children: [[Mary Pinchot Meyer|Mary Eno]] and Antoinette "Tony" Pinchot.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=enxRAAAAIBAJ&sjid=BmgDAAAAIBAJ&pg=3869,464003&dq=amos+pinchot+divorce&hl=en|title=Amos Pinchot Married To Magazine Writer|date=August 10, 1919|work=The Gazette Times|page=3|accessdate=December 3, 2012}}{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/obituaries/2011/11/14/gIQAazbbMN_story.html|title=Antoinette Pinchot Bradlee, former wife of prominent Washington Post executive editor Benjamin C. Bradlee, dies at 87|last=Bernstein|first=Adam|date=November 4, 2011|publisher=washingtonpost.com|accessdate=December 3, 2012}} ==Career== At the age of nineteen, Pinchot was discovered by [[Max Reinhardt]] while traveling on an ocean liner with her mother. Reinhardt cast her as a nun who runs away from a convent in the Broadway production of [[Karl Vollmoller]]'s ''[[The Miracle (play)|The Miracle]]''.{{harv|Gaston|2009|pp=7, 12}} Pinchot's appearance in the play caused a sensation and led to her receiving considerable attention from the press who named her "the loveliest woman in America".{{cite book|last=Burleigh|first=Nina |title=A Very Private Woman: The Life and Unsolved Murder of Presidential Mistress Mary Meyer|year=2009|publisher=Random House, Inc.|isbn=0-307-57417-2|page=47}}{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/06/05/AR2008060503611.html|title=A Complicated Pedigree|last=See|first=Carolyn|date=June 6, 2008|publisher=washingtonpost.com|accessdate=December 13, 2012}} Reinhardt later cast her in productions of [[William Shakespeare]]'s ''[[A Midsummer Night's Dream]]'' and [[Franz Werfel]]'s ''[[The Eternal Road (opera)|The Eternal Road]]''. She made her only film appearance in the 1935 adaptation of ''[[The Three Musketeers (1935 film)|The Three Musketeers]]'', as Queen Anne. ==Personal life== Pinchot married William "Big Bill" Gaston (who was previously married to [[Kay Francis]]), on January 26, 1928. The couple had two children, William Alexander Gaston and James Pinchot Gaston.{{cite book|last1=Kear|first1=Lynn |last2=Rossman|first2=John |title=Kay Francis: A Passionate Life and Career|year=2006|publisher=McFarland|isbn=0-7864-2366-8|page=33}}{{harv|Gaston|2009|pp=43, 49}} In 1933, Pinchot and Gaston separated. They remained married but were estranged at the time of Pinchot's death.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1946&dat=19380122&id=_ooxAAAAIBAJ&sjid=WKgFAAAAIBAJ&pg=6776,2542546|title=Rosamond Pinchot, Actress, A Suicide|date=January 24, 1938|work=The Montreal Gazette|page=2|accessdate=December 13, 2012}} ==Death== On the morning of January 24, 1938, a cook found Pinchot's body in the front seat of her car parked in the garage of a rented estate in [[Old Brookville, New York]].{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=U0syAAAAIBAJ&sjid=p68FAAAAIBAJ&pg=4802,1271323&dq=rosamond+pinchot&hl=en|title=Rosamond Pinchot Takes Own Life|date=January 24, 1938|work=The Daily Times|page=1|accessdate=December 13, 2012}} Her death was later determined to be caused by [[asphyxia]] due to [[carbon monoxide poisoning]] and was ruled a suicide.{{cite news|title=ROSAMOND PINCHOT ENDS LIFE IN GARAGE; Actress of 'The Miracle' Fame Dies of Fumes in Auto at Long Island Home|date=January 25, 1938|work=The New York Times|page=1}} Pinchot left two suicide notes of which the contents were never made public.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=zzYxAAAAIBAJ&sjid=LVADAAAAIBAJ&pg=6236,1084975&dq=rosamond+pinchot+funeral&hl=en|title=Pinchot Rites Are Arranged|date=January 25, 1938|work=Prescott Evening Courier|page=8|accessdate=December 13, 2012}} Pinchot's funeral was held at her mother's townhouse in New York City on January 26, 1938, her tenth wedding anniversary. She was buried in the Pinchot family plot in Milford Cemetery in [[Milford, Pennsylvania]].{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=avYaAAAAIBAJ&sjid=Dk0EAAAAIBAJ&pg=2182,3916486&dq=rosamond+pinchot+mildford&hl=en|title=Rosamond Pinchot Buried In Family Lot|date=January 26, 1938|work=The Pittsburgh Press|page=2|accessdate=December 13, 2012}} ==Stage credits== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Date ! Production ! Role |- | January 16 – June 1924 | ''[[The Miracle (play)|The Miracle]]'' | The Nun |- | May 31 – June 1926 | ''[[Henry IV, Part 2]]'' | John of Lancaster |- | November 17 – December 1927 | ''[[A Midsummer Night's Dream]]'' | Helena |- | December 7 – December 1927 | ''Jederman'' | Lady |- | December 20, 1927 – January 1928 | ''Danton's Tod'' | Marion |- | October 6 – November 1936 | ''[[St Helena (play)|St Helena]]'' | Countess Bertrand |- | January 7 – May 15, 1937 | ''[[The Eternal Road (opera)|The Eternal Road]]'' | Bath-Sheba |- |} ==Footnotes== {{Reflist|2}} ==References== * Gaston, Bibi (2009), ''The Loveliest Woman in America: A Tragic Actress, Her Lost Diaries, and Her Granddaughter's Search for Home'', HarperCollins, {{ISBN|0-06-085771-4}} ==External links== {{Portal|Biography}} * {{IBDB name}} * {{IMDb name|0683877}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Pinchot, Rosamond}} [[Category:1904 births]] [[Category:1938 deaths]] [[Category:20th-century American actresses]] [[Category:Actresses from New York City]] [[Category:American film actresses]] [[Category:American socialites]] [[Category:American actresses who committed suicide]] [[Category:American stage actresses]] [[Category:Burials in Pennsylvania]] [[Category:American people of French descent]] [[Category:Deaths from asphyxiation]] [[Category:Dudley–Winthrop family]] [[Category:Female suicides]] [[Category:Pinchot family]] [[Category:Socialites who committed suicide]] [[Category:Suicides by carbon monoxide poisoning]] [[Category:Suicides in New York (state)]]

{{Infobox person | honorific_prefix = | name = Rubén Espinosa<!-- include middle initial, if not specified in birth_name --> | honorific_suffix = | image = Ruben-Espinosa-.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | pronunciation = | birth_name = Rubén Manuel Espinosa Becerril | birth_date = November 29, 1983 | birth_place = Mexico City, Mexico | baptised = <!-- will not display if birth_date is entered --> | disappeared_date = <!-- {{disappeared date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} (disappeared date then birth date) --> | disappeared_place = | disappeared_status = | death_date = July 31, 2015 | death_place = Mexico City, Mexico | death_cause = Murder from gunfire | body_discovered = | resting_place = Panteón De Dolores, Mexico | resting_place_coordinates = <!-- {{coord|LAT|LONG|type:landmark|display=inline}} --> | monuments = | residence = | nationality = Mexican | other_names = | citizenship = | education = | alma_mater = | occupation = Photojournalist | years_active = | era = | employer = AVC News agency, ''Proceso'' and ''Cuartoscuro'' magazines | organization = | agent = <!-- Discouraged in most cases, specifically when promotional, and requiring a reliable source --> | known_for = Social Movements | notable_works = <!-- produces label "Notable work"; may be overridden by |credits=, which produces label "Notable credit(s)"; or by |works=, which produces label "Works" --> | style = | home_town = | salary = | net_worth = <!-- Net worth should be supported with a citation from a reliable source --> | height = <!-- "X cm", "X m" or "X ft Y in" plus optional reference (conversions are automatic) --> | weight = <!-- "X kg", "X lb" or "X st Y lb" plus optional reference (conversions are automatic) --> | television = | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | movement = | opponents = | boards = | religion = <!-- Religion should be supported with a citation from a reliable source --> | denomination = <!-- Denomination should be supported with a citation from a reliable source --> | criminal_charge = <!-- Criminality parameters should be supported with citations from reliable sources --> | criminal_penalty = | criminal_status = | children = | parents = | relatives = | callsign = | awards = | website = <!-- {{URL|example.com}} --> | module = | module2 = | module3 = | module4 = | module5 = | module6 = | signature = | signature_size = | signature_alt = | footnotes = | ethnicity = <!-- Ethnicity should be supported with a citation from a reliable source --> | burial_place = <!-- may be used instead of resting_place and resting_place_coordinates (displays "Burial place" as label) --> | burial_coordinates = <!-- {{coord|LAT|LONG|type:landmark|display=inline}} --> | spouse = <!-- Use article title or common name --> | partner = <!-- (unmarried long-term partner) --> }}'''Rubén Manuel Espinosa Becerril''' (29 November 1983 – 31 July 2015) was a Mexican self-taught photographer and journalist. He worked for AVC News agency and ''[[Proceso (magazine)|Proceso]]'' and ''Cuartoscuro'' magazines. He covered daily news and social protests.<ref name="mx">{{cite web|url=http://homozapping.com.mx/2015/08/quiere-miguel-mancera-convertirse-en-otro-javier-duarte-comunicado-sobre-el-asesinato-de-ruben-espinosa-y-semblanza/|title=¿Quiere Miguel Mancera convertirse en otro Javier Duarte? Comunicado sobre el asesinato de Rubén Espinosa (y semblanza) - Homozapping|publisher=}}</ref> He documented several protests where individuals were assaulted. Espinosa was killed in Narvate, [[Mexico City]], [[Mexico]] along with four women.<ref name="proceso1">{{cite web|url=http://www.proceso.com.mx/?p=412006|title=Asesinan en el DF a Rubén Espinosa, fotoperiodista de Proceso|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150802171157/http://www.proceso.com.mx/?p=412006|archivedate=2 August 2015|work=Proceso}}</ref>
== Personal == Espinosa was born in Mexico City, Mexico.<ref name="mx" />
== Career == For the majority of his career, Espinosa concentrated on social movements and protests. As a self-taught photographer and journalist, he began his career with Eclipse Photo in Mexico City, Mexico.<ref name="mx" /> While with Eclipse Photo, his primary job was photography. In 2009, he was hired by [[Javier Duarte de Ochoa|Javier Duarte]] during his campaign as governor.<ref name="thedailybeast">{{cite web|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2015/08/12/did-a-mexican-governor-have-this-journalist-killed-over-an-unflattering-photo.html|title=Did a Mexican Governor Have This Journalist Killed Over an Unflattering Photo?|work=The Daily Beast}}</ref> Espinosa also worked in [[Xalapa|Xalapa, Mexico]] for seven years. Xalapa is considered one of the most dangerous place to practice journalism.<ref name="terra">{{cite web|url=http://noticias.terra.com/mundo/latinoamerica/la-sip-condena-el-asesinato-del-periodista-mexicano-ruben-espinosa,386bc8ac2bc61414052315e6f6e6ea635e63RCRD.html|title=La SIP condena el asesinato del periodista mexicano Rubén Espinosa|date=3 August 2015|work=Terra}}</ref> Espinosa's interest in social movements led him find employment elsewhere. In [[Veracruz]], Espinosa became a correspondent for ''Proceso'' and ''Cuartoscuro'' magazines. During his employment with the magazine, Espinosa voiced his opinion regarding the treatment journalists in Mexico.<ref name="bbc1">{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-latin-america-33846438|title=Impunity feared in Mexico photojournalist's murder|work=BBC News}}</ref>
== Death == <!--begin wikitable-->{{Location map+|Mexico| width = 280 | float = left |caption= Rubén Espinosa was killed in Mexico City, Mexico. |alt = THE ADDED CITY is located in Mexico. |AlternativeMap = Mexico States blank map.svg |places= {{Location map~ | Mexico |lat_deg=19 |lat_min=25 |lat_sec=57 |lat_dir=N |lon_deg=99 |lon_min=07 |lon_sec=59 |lon_dir=W |position=left |background=#FFFFFF |label=Mexico City }} | position = left }}Before his death, Espinosa had received deadly threats. Espinosa began to receive threats towards him after the release of a photo of Duarte. During a social protest Espinosa was grabbed and told to quit taking photos or else he would end up like other dead journalists.<ref name="latincorrespondent">{{cite web|url=http://latincorrespondent.com/2015/08/murder-mexican-journalist-ruben-espinosa-raises-questions-censorship-corruption/|title=Murder of Mexican journalist Rubén Espinosa, raises questions about censorship and corruption|publisher=|author=Paul Imison}}</ref> Espinosa had also previously reported men standing outside his house and giving him intimidating glares and gestures. In June 2015, Espinosa decided to leave Veracruz and return to Mexico City.<ref name="elfinanciero">{{cite web|url=http://www.elfinanciero.com.mx/nacional/por-el-miedo-a-que-lo-mataran-hasta-su-perro-dejo-en-veracruz.html|title=Por el miedo a que lo mataran, hasta su perro dejó en Veracruz|publisher=}}</ref> He reported experiencing symptoms of [[Posttraumatic stress disorder|PTSD]].<ref name="fpif">{{cite web|url=http://fpif.org/in-mexico-hunted-down-for-speaking-out/|title=In Mexico, Hunted Down for Speaking Out|work=Foreign Policy In Focus}}</ref><ref name="ap2">{{cite web|url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/bef4e1fece1149279bafccc5a3276c5f/journalist-slain-mexico-city-had-signs-torture|title=Gov't reaction criticized in case of Mexico slain journalist|work=The Big Story}}</ref> Espinosa left his friends and even his dog Cosmos in Veracruz to find safety in Mexico City, which was a known refuge for journalists.<ref name="bbc5">{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-latin-america-33771875|title=Mexico outraged over journalist Ruben Espinosa's murder|work=BBC News}}</ref>
Espinosa was found dead on 31 July 2015 with four female victims.<ref name="unesco">{{cite web|url=http://www.unesco.org/new/en/media-services/single-view/news/unesco_director_general_condemns_the_killing_of_mexican_photojournalist_ruben_espinosa/#.VqTwfyorJaQ|title=UNESCO Director General condemns the killing of Mexican photojournalist Ruben Espinosa - United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization|publisher=}}</ref><ref name="bbc4">{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.com/mundo/noticias/2015/08/150802_mexico_muerte_ruben_espinosa_men|title=Conmoción por asesinato de periodista Rubén Espinosa en Ciudad de México|work=BBC Mundo}}</ref> All five were found beaten and shot execution style.<ref name="theguardian4">{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/aug/02/mexican-photojournalist-ruben-espinosa-found-dead-in-capital|title=Mexican photojournalist Rubén Espinosa found dead in capital|work=the Guardian}}</ref> The victims also had various signs of torture on their bodies.<ref name="theguardian2">{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/aug/02/mexican-photojournalist-killed-ruben-espinosa-tortured|title=Mexican photojournalist found dead was likely tortured, activists say|work=the Guardian}}</ref> The women who were found had all been sexually assaulted by the culprits.<ref name="dailymail2">{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-3187121/Police-arrest-serial-rapist-brutal-murder-Mexican-journalist-fingerprints-crime-scene.html|title=Police arrest serial rapist for murder of Mexican journalist Ruben Espinosa|date=6 August 2015|work=Mail Online}}</ref> The names of the women were not released at the time until days later.<ref name="theguardian3">{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/aug/12/ruben-espinosa-female-murders-mexico-media|title=Mexico's Ruben Espinosa case: female victims treated as afterthoughts by press|author=Nina Lakhani|work=the Guardian}}</ref><ref name="cnn1">{{cite web|url=http://mexico.cnn.com/nacional/2015/08/02/10-datos-clave-sobre-el-caso-de-multihomicidio-en-la-colonia-narvarte|title=10 datos clave sobre el caso de multihomicidio en la colonia Narvarte|date=2 August 2015|publisher=}}</ref> The authorities believe that deaths occurred between 9 a.m. and 3 p.m. A final text message was placed by Espinosa at 2:13 p.m.<ref name="bbc3">{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-latin-america-33753065|title=Mexican photojournalist Ruben Espinosa found dead|work=BBC News}}</ref><ref name="cnn4">{{cite web|url=http://mexico.cnn.com/nacional/2015/08/08/esta-fue-la-ultima-conversacion-del-fotoperiodista-ruben-espinosa|title=¿Esta fue la última conversación del fotoperiodista Rubén Espinosa?|date=8 August 2015|publisher=}}</ref>
===Investigation=== Video surveillance caught three suspects walking out of the apartment. One of the suspects took the car of a victim and drove off with it. The car was later found abandoned on the outskirts of Mexico City.<ref name="bbc6">{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-latin-america-33786679|title=Mexico seeks suspects in journalist Espinosa's murder|work=BBC News}}</ref> The case was viewed as a burglary due to the various objects taken from the residence.<ref name="ap2"/> In August 2015, an unnamed serial rapist was arrested for the deaths of the victims. His fingerprints matched up to the evidence found in the apartment. There is still an ongoing investigation for the other two suspects caught on the surveillance video.<ref name="dailymail2"/> The police department in charge of the investigation do have fifteen statements as well as evidence and photographs.<ref name="cnn7">{{cite web|url=http://mexico.cnn.com/nacional/2015/08/02/fotoperiodista-ruben-espinosa-veracruz-narvarte-multihomicidio-periodismo|title=La PGJDF investiga homicidio y robo por el multiasesinato en la Narvarte|publisher=}}</ref>
== Context == Espinosa had reported threats being made towards him before his death. Espinosa had previously had several run ins with the law while covering several social movements.<ref name="cjfe">{{cite web|url=http://www.cjfe.org/deeply_troubled_by_killing_of_mexican_photojournalist_rub_n_espinosa|title=Deeply troubled by killing of Mexican photojournalist Rubén Espinosa|work=CJFE - Canadian Journalists for Free Expression}}</ref> In 2012, Espinosa covered a student protest against [[Javier Duarte de Ochoa|Governor Javier Duarte]] during the anniversary of the revolution.<ref name="cpj">{{cite web|url=https://cpj.org/killed/2015/ruben-espinosa-becerril.php|title=Rubén Espinosa Becerril|publisher=}}</ref> During the protest Espinosa was grabbed and the man stated "Stop taking pictures if you don't want to end up like Regina".<ref name="proceso2">{{cite web|url=http://www.proceso.com.mx/?p=412068|title=Rubén Espinosa, un fotógrafo 'incómodo' para el gobierno de Duarte - Proceso|author=Marcela Turati|work=Proceso}}</ref> [[Regina Martínez Pérez|Regina Martinez Perez]], was also a correspondent for ''Proceso'' and ''Cuartoscuro'' magazines.<ref name="bbc2">{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.com/mundo/noticias/2015/08/150803_mexico_asesinato_espinosa_mujeres_am|title=Quiénes eran las cuatro mujeres asesinadas junto al periodista Rubén Espinosa en México|work=BBC Mundo}}</ref> She had recently been killed after reporting on state official.<ref name="spiegel">{{cite web|url=http://www.spiegel.de/kultur/gesellschaft/mexiko-fotoreporter-ruben-espinosa-getoetet-a-1046373.html|title=Mexiko: Fotoreporter Rubén Espinosa getötet|date=2 August 2015|author=SPIEGEL ONLINE, Hamburg, Germany|work=SPIEGEL ONLINE}}</ref> Espinosa released a photograph of Governor Javier Duarte. The photograph showed Governor Duarte wearing a police cap and his stomach hanging over and below his belt. Espinosa received multiple threats after the release of the photograph.<ref name="csmonitor">{{cite web|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Americas/2015/0803/Mexico-City-Why-didn-t-slain-journalist-Ruben-Espinosa-seek-protection|title=Mexico City: Why didn't slain journalist Ruben Espinosa seek protection?|date=3 August 2015|author=The Christian Science Monitor|work=The Christian Science Monitor}}</ref> The governor was outraged by the photograph and article. He sent people to find and buy out all the prints released in various locations.<ref name="sinembargo2">{{cite web|url=http://www.sinembargo.mx/02-08-2015/1436027|title=LA FOTO DE RUBÉN ESPINOSA QUE ENCABRONÓ AL GOBERNADOR DE VERACRUZ|author=Redacción / Sin Embargo|work=SinEmbargo MX}}</ref> Espinosa decided to flee Veracruz and find refugee in Mexico City, Mexico. His decision was made after seeing men standing outside of his house three separate times. He had reported that the men were giving him intimidating glances and gestures.<ref name="cpj" /> On 31 July 2015 Espinosa was found alongside four other women. The women were identified as Nadia Vera, Yesenia Quiroz, Mile Virginia Martin, and Alejandra Negrete.<ref name="fpif" /><ref name="newyorker">{{cite web|url=http://www.newyorker.com/news/news-desk/who-killed-ruben-espinosa-and-nadia-vera|title=Who Killed Rubén Espinosa and Nadia Vera?|date=14 August 2015|author=Francisco Goldman|work=The New Yorker}}</ref><ref name="sinembargo1">{{cite web|url=http://www.sinembargo.mx/06-08-2015/1441533|title=Colombia identifica a su ciudadana asesinada en la Narvarte y exige que el crimen no quede impune|author=Redacción / Sin Embargo|work=SinEmbargo MX}}</ref><ref name="cnn2">{{cite web|url=http://mexico.cnn.com/nacional/2015/08/10/espinosa-dejo-veracruz-tras-una-agresion-de-encapuchados-dice-duarte|title=Espinosa dejó Veracruz tras una agresión de encapuchados, dice Duarte|date=10 August 2015|publisher=}}</ref> His and the bodies of the women were all found killed execution style.<ref name="latincorrespondent" /> Mile Virginia Marin was the last of the victims to be identified due to having a Colombian origin.<ref name="bolsamania">{{cite web|url=http://www.bolsamania.com/colombia/noticias/justicia/la-colombiana-que-murio-junto-al-periodista-mexicano-ruben-espinosa--822979.html|title=La colombiana que murió junto al periodista mexicano Rubén Espinosa|date=4 August 2015|publisher=|author=Web Financial Group, S.A.}}</ref> Espinosa is the seventh journalist that has been killed in Mexico in the year 2015.<ref name="nytimes">{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/03/world/americas/huge-rally-over-killing-of-mexican-journalist.html|title=Huge Mexico City Rally Over Killing of Journalist|date=3 August 2015|work=The New York Times}}</ref> Since 2011 under Javier Duarte's govern of Mexico 15 journalist have been killed.<ref name="elpais">{{cite web|url=http://internacional.elpais.com/internacional/2015/08/02/actualidad/1438471146_330192.html|title=Rubén Espinosa: Asesinado en México un fotoperiodista que había recibido amenazas - Internacional - EL PAÍS|date=2 August 2015|author=Ediciones El País|work=EL PAÍS}}</ref> [[Regina Martínez Pérez|Regina Martinez Pérez]], [[Miguel Ángel López Velasco|Miguel Angel Lopez Velasco]], [[Yolanda Ordaz de la Cruz]], and the other journalist who have been murdered all have one similar thing. All their murders have had no responsible culprit punished.<ref name="analisisafondo">{{cite web|url=http://www.analisisafondo.com/index.php/sociedad/derechos-humanos/item/19056-javier-duarte-gobernador-bajo-sospecha|title=ANÁLISIS A FONDO - Javier Duarte, ¿gobernador bajo sospecha?|publisher=|author=Roberto Vizcaíno}}</ref> Regina Martinez Pérez worked alongside Espinosa in the past and was murdered on 28 April 2012.<ref name="proceso3">{{cite web|url=http://www.proceso.com.mx/?p=412047|title=Se extiende a estados repudio por muerte de fotoperiodista|author=La Redacción|work=Proceso}}</ref> According to [[Reporters Without Borders|Reporters without Borders]], In 2014 Mexico was the named the 6th country in the world with high rates of journalist being killed. After the death of Espinosa protesters gathered holding cameras and signs that stated "not one more".<ref name="cnn4" /> The protesters also held signs stating "How many more Javier Duarte?".<ref name="proceso5">{{cite web|url=http://ruben.proceso.com.mx/|title=Rubén Espinosa (1984-2015)|work=Rubén Espinosa (1984-2015)}}</ref> During his funeral journalist traveled to be present. They covered his grave with cameras.<ref name="sinembargo3">{{cite web|url=http://www.sinembargo.mx/03-08-2015/1437138|title=Familiares, compañeros y amigos dan último adiós al fotoperiodista Rubén Espinosa|author=Redacción / Sin Embargo|work=SinEmbargo MX}}</ref> State and Legislative committees deal with the complaints made by reporters who has been attacked, harassed, or abused. However, nothing is ever resolved through the offices.<ref name="josecardenas">{{cite web|url=http://josecardenas.com/2015/08/morir-de-miedo/|title=Morir de miedo|author=Oscar Olguin|work=José Cárdenas}}</ref>
== Impact == According to [[Article 19]], Espinosa is the 88th journalist that has been killed in Mexico.<ref name="npr">{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2015/08/02/428655196/mexican-photojournalist-found-dead-in-countrys-capital|title=Mexican Photojournalist Found Dead In Country's Capital|date=2 August 2015|work=NPR.org}}</ref> Espinosa decided to flee to Mexico City in seek of refugee. Until his death Mexico City was seen as a refugee for journalist who were being threatened.<ref name="npr" /> Citizens have become angry and disheartened at the lack of safety and protection Governor Duarte has provided for journalists.<ref name="proceso4">{{cite web|url=http://www.proceso.com.mx/?p=412259|title=Rubén Espinosa y la línea periodística|author=José Gil Olmos|work=Proceso}}</ref><ref name="cnn5">{{cite web|url=http://www.cnnmexico.com/nacional/2015/08/03/proceso-y-cuartoscuro-exigen-investigacion-de-amenazas-a-espinosa|title='Proceso' y 'Cuartoscuro' exigen investigación de amenazas a Espinosa|date=3 August 2015|publisher=}}</ref> As a self-taught journalist and photographer, Espinosa was motivated and felt strongly about journalist rights in Mexico.<ref name="cctvamerica">{{cite web|url=http://www.cctv-america.com/2015/08/30/murder-of-journalist-ruben-espinosa-in-mexico-city-sparks-outrage|title=Murder of journalist Ruben Espinosa in Mexico City sparks outrage|work=CCTV America}}</ref> However, after reporting and photographing several brutal attacks and protests Espinosa began to be a target of threats.<ref name="pen">{{cite web|url=http://www.pen.org/defending-writers/ruben-espinosa|title=Ruben Espinosa - PEN American Center|publisher=}}</ref> After his death Mexico City was no longer a place safe for journalist seeking refugee.<ref name="mx" /> Hundreds of journalist and photographers from around the world published a letter in [[PEN American Center|PEN America]] asking for a clear notice of what occurred that day and who was responsible. They urged for a further investigation into his death.<ref name="cnnespanol">{{cite web|url=http://cnnespanol.cnn.com/2015/08/16/intelectuales-y-periodistas-de-todo-el-mundo-exigen-aclarar-del-asesinato-del-reportero-ruben-espinosa/|title=Intelectuales y periodistas de todo el mundo exigen aclarar del asesinato del reportero Rubén Espinosa|work=CNNEspañol.com}}</ref>
== Reactions == [[File:Marcha por Rubén Espinosa, periodista asesinado (2).jpg|thumb|A march held after the death of Rubén Espinosa.]] After the death of Espinosa, several protesters have gathered in several different locations in his honor.<ref name="cnn3">{{cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/08/03/americas/mexico-city-photographer-killed/|title=Mexican journalist's death 'new peak' in violence|date=4 August 2015|author=Elwyn Lopez and Catherine E. Shoichet, CNN|work=CNN}}</ref><ref name="cnn6">{{cite web|url=http://mexico.cnn.com/nacional/2015/08/03/la-onu-condena-el-asesinato-del-fotoperiodista-ruben-espinosa|title=La ONU condena el asesinato del fotoperiodista Rubén Espinosa|date=3 August 2015|publisher=}}</ref> In Mexico City a demonstration spread a network tag #JusticiaparaRubén to continue spreading his life story as well as his troubling death.<ref name="dailymail2"/> A colleague of his stated "He was both a photographer and activist...But most of all he was a great friend".<ref name="latincorrespondent" /> The Office of the High Commissioner For Human Rights [[Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights|(OHCHR)]] stated after the death of Espinosa: "If the investigations confirm that this aberrant multiple homicide is related to Espinosa's work as a journalist, then we are in the presence of a grave act against freedom of expression".<ref name="newyorker" />
==See also== * [[Mexican Drug War]] * [[List of journalists and media workers killed in Mexico]]
== References == {{Reflist|30em}}

{{other people|Sidney Brown}}
{{Infobox medical person | honorific_prefix = [[Dame]] | name = Sidney Jane Browne | honorific_suffix = <small>[[Order of the British Empire|GBE]] [[Royal Red Cross|RRC]]</small> | image =Dame Sidney Browne Rrc- the Matron-in Chief of the T F Nursing Service Art.IWMART2768.jpg | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date|df=yes|1850|01|05}} | birth_place = [[Bexley]], [[Kent, England|Kent]], England | death_date = {{death date and age |1941|08|13|1850|01|05 |df=yes}} | death_place = [[Cheltenham]], [[Gloucestershire]], England | death_cause = | nationality = British | citizenship = | education = | occupation = Nurse | years_active = | known_for = First President of the [[Royal College of Nursing]] | relations = | signature = | profession = nurse leader | field = | work_institutions = | specialism = | research_field = | prizes = | child = | module2 = }} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2017}} {{Use British English|date=March 2017}}
'''Dame Sidney Jane Browne''', [[Order of the British Empire|GBE]], [[Royal Red Cross|RRC]] (5 January 1850 – 13 August 1941) was the first appointed Matron-in-Chief of the newly formed [[Queen Alexandra's Imperial Military Nursing Service]]. After she retired from the QAIMNS she was appointed as Matron-in-Chief of the [[Territorial Force Nursing Service]]. Browne was appointed [[Dame Grand Cross of the Order of the British Empire]] (GBE) in 1918.
In 1922 she became the first President of the [[Royal College of Nursing]] a post she held till 1925<ref name=BJN86>{{cite journal|url=http://rcnarchive.rcn.org.uk/data/VOLUME086-1938/page020-volume60-12thjanuarymay1918.pdf|title=Queen Alexandra's Imperial Military Nursing Service - New Matron-in-Chief|journal=The British Journal of Nursing|volume=60|pages=20|date=12 January 1918|accessdate=2009-06-21}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref>
In 1918, Browne told her nurses, 'Put a high ideal before you, and do your future service in a greater strength than your own, and your life will be for the betterment of the world.' <ref name=RCNwebsite> {{cite web | title=RCN Presidents Exhibition =| url =https://www.rcn.org.uk/centenary/projects/presidents-exhibition|accessdate=2017-12-19}}</ref>
Browne lived in Cheltenham with her friend Hilda Hoole from 1927. Browne died on 13 August 1941, with her funeral taking place at St Stephen’s Church Cheltenham.
In December 2017 a [[blue plaque]] was unveiled at her former home, 11 Tivoli Road, by the [[Cheltenham Civic Society]] and the [[Royal College of Nursing]]. <ref name=GloucestershireLive>{{cite journal|url=http://www.gloucestershirelive.co.uk/news/cheltenham-news/cheltenham-nursing-pioneer-dame-sidney-898368 |title=Cheltenham nursing pioneer Dame Sidney Brown to get blue plaque |publisher=Gloucestershirelive|date=9 December 2017|accessdate=2017-12-19}}</ref>
== Early life == Sidney Browne was born in [[Bexley]].<ref name="Susan McGann">{{Cite web|url=http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/49193|title=Browne, Dame Sidney Jane (1850–1941)|last=McGann|first=Susan|date=2004|website=www.oxforddnb.com|publisher=Oxford University Press|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-05-10}}</ref> She grew up in a medical family, with a surgeon father and two brothers who were doctors.
== Nursing Career == Browne attended a series of lectures given by the pioneering district nurse [[Florence Lees]] which prompted her interest in nursing as a career.
In 1878 she briefly started nursing at the Guest Hospital, [[Dudley]] and later that year entered training at the District Hospital [[West Bromwich]] 1878-1882. In 1882 Browne worked as Staff Nurse at [[St Bartholomew's Hospital]] for a year, where she was influenced by the matron, Ethel Manson (later Mrs [[Ethel Gordon Fenwick]]). Browne was one of the first nurses registered with the [[British Nurses' Association]] on 7 March 1890, the precursor of the [[State Register of Nurses]]. <ref name= KCLNurses>{{Cite web |title = Browne, Sidney Jane | url = http://www.kingscollections.org/nurses/a-c/browne-sidney-jane | accessdate = 19 December 2017}}</ref>
In 1883 Browne joined the [[Army Nursing Service]], where she was posted to the [[Netley Hospital|Royal Victoria Hospital]], [[Netley]] and in 1884 had her first overseas posting during the [[Anglo-Egyptian War (1882)|Egyptian War]]. For her work in the [[Sudan War]]s she received the Khedive's Star and the Egyptian medal and bar (1885). Browne's postings took her to [[Malta]] (1887-1890), [[Ireland]] ([[Curragh Camp]]), [[Woolwich]] ([[Herbert Hospital]]) and [[Aldershot]], rising steadily through the ranks. <ref name=KCLNurses/>
Browne was posted to active service in the [[South African War]] from October 1899 where over the next three years she was superintending sister at three different base hospitals, for which she received the [[Royal Red Cross]]. Significant reforms of medical services led to the establishment of an army nursing service. In 1902 Browne was returned to England for her next post as the first [[Matron-in Chief]] of the newly created [[Queen Alexandra's Imperial Military Nursing Service]] (QAIMNS) - now [[Queen Alexandra's Royal Army Nursing Corps]] - where she introduced rigorous training procedures. She retired from the Army in 1906 at age 55, which gave her the time to be an active campaigner for the state registration of nurses. <ref name="Susan McGann"/>
Browne was still concerned about the lack of trained nurses available to the Army and with [[Elisabeth Haldane]] established the [[Territorial Force Nursing Service]], a civilian trained nursing reserve, in 1908, for which she became Matron-in-Chief from 1910. With the outbreak of the [[First World War]] in 1914, Browne was responsible for the mobilisation of the [[Territorial Force Nursing Service]], and its expansion from 3,000 to 7,000 nurses. Browne travelled across Britain and abroad inspecting living and working conditions of her nursing staff. <ref name="Susan McGann"/>
In 1916 Browne, who had long supported the nursing state registration bill, agreed that the time was right for a College of Nursing to be established. Both Browne and [[Sarah Swift]] had worked as [[Matron-in-Chief]] during the [[First World War]], and both became actively involved in what was to become the [[Royal College of Nursing]]. Browne was a member of the first [[Royal College of Nursing]] Council from 1917 until her retirement in 1927 and was the first Honorary Treasurer of the College as well as the inaugural President. <ref name="Susan McGann"/>
At an investiture on 31 July 1919 Browne was recognised for her work in the [[First World War]] when she was appointed [[Dame Grand Cross]] (military division) of the [[Most Excellent Order of the British Empire]] (GBE). She received many honours for her work including an honorary degree in 1925 from [[Leeds University]], the freedom of [[West Bromwich]]; and in July 1927, she was awarded the [[International Florence Nightingale Medal]] by the [[League of Red Cross Societies]]. <ref name="Susan McGann"/>
==References== {{reflist}} *Oxford Dictionary of National Biography *Anne Summers, Angels and Citizens. Routledge & Kegan Paul, 1988
==Sources== *[http://www.london-gazette.co.uk/issues/27944/pages/5870 Gazette Issue 27944 published on the 28 August 1906] :''"Miss Sidney J. Browne, R.R.C., late Matron-in-Chief, is granted permission to retain the Badge of Queen Alexandra's Imperial Military Nursing Service, in recognition of her long and meritorious service."'' (dated 28 August 1906) *[http://www.london-gazette.co.uk/issues/31097/supplements/83 Gazette Issue 31097 published on the 31 December 1918] :''"The King has been graciously pleased to give orders for the following promotions in and appointments to the Most Excellent Order of the British Empire, for valuable services rendered in connection with the War [World War I];-- To be a Dame Grand Cross of the Military Division of the said Most Excellent Order: -- Miss Sidney Jane Browne, R.R.C., Matron-in-Chief, Territorial Nursing Service."'' (dated 31 December 1918) *{{cite book|author = McGann, Susan|year = 1992| title = Battle of the Nurses: a study of eight women who influenced the development of professional nursing 1880-1930|location = London|publisher = Scutari|isbn = 1-871364-62-0}}
==External links== *[http://rcnarchive.rcn.org.uk/.../page020-volume60-12thjanuary1918.pdf RCN archives] *[http://www.qaranc.co.uk/matroninchiefs.php QARANC]

revision.text:
{{Euthanasia}} '''Suicide tourism''', or '''euthanasia tourism''', is the practice of potential suicide candidates travelling to a jurisdiction to commit [[assisted suicide]] or [[suicide]]. In some jurisdictions, assisted suicide is legal.
==Status in various countries==
===Cambodia=== An American expatriate who set up websites offering to help people make arrangements to kill themselves in Cambodia shut the sites down in 2005, saying he hoped to avoid problems with the authorities.<ref>[https://www.usatoday.com/travel/news/2005-11-04-suicide-tourism_x.htm "Suicide-tourism websites shut down,"] ''USA Today'' (04-11-2005). Retrieved 4 May 2014.</ref>
===Mexico=== {{Main|Euthanasia in Mexico}} A drug known as liquid [[pentobarbital]] is used by owners to euthanize pets. When given to humans, the drug can give them a painless death in under one hour. The pet shops across Mexico have such drugs. As a result, tourists from across the globe seeking to terminate their own lives were reported to be flying out to Mexico.<ref name="reuters-mx">{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/lifestyleMolt/idUSN0329945820080603?sp=true|title=Euthanasia tourists snap up pet shop drug in Mexico|last=Emmott|first=Robin |author2=Hernández, Magdiel |author3=Bremer, Catherine |author4=Chiacu, Doina|date=2008-06-03|publisher=Reuters|accessdate=2009-09-25|location=Nuevo Laredo, Mexico}}</ref><ref>Davies, Julie-Anne, [http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/nation/nitschke-diy-kit-upsets-british/story-e6frg6nf-1225700242552 "Nitschke DIY kit upsets British"], ''[[The Australian]]'', April 20, 2009. They asked Dr. [[Philip Nitschke]] about it. "As revealed in The Australian last month, Exit members are obtaining Nembutal from an online mail order supplier in Mexico. Others travel to Mexico and smuggle the drug home in their luggage. The kits, which will retail for $50, include a syringe that allows users to extract half a millilitre of the solution. 'Clearly, sterility doesn't matter given that death is the desired outcome,' Dr Nitschke said. 'People want reassurance they've not just bought a bottle of water.'" </ref><ref>[http://www.internationaltaskforce.org/iua49.htm "News briefs from home and abroad"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090808220725/http://www.internationaltaskforce.org/iua49.htm |date=2009-08-08 }}, ''The International Task Force on Euthanasia and Assisted Suicide'', Year 2009, Volume 23, Number 3. "Australia's Dr. Death, Dr. Philip Nitschke, has been on the road proffering his latest invention, a do-it-yourself kit to test the quality and potency of the barbiturate Nembutal. ... So Nitschke tells the elderly and not-so-elderly that the drug is both available and cheap in Mexico. But not all Mexican vendors are reputable, so his euthanasia test kit is needed to make sure that people have the real thing and the potency is truly deadly. ..." [The Australian, 4/20/09]</ref>
===Netherlands=== {{Main|Euthanasia in the Netherlands}} Critics have claimed that the Dutch initiative for euthanasia will trigger a wave of "euthanasia tourism".{{Citation needed|date=May 2014}} However, a clause insisting on a well-established relationship between doctor and patient is designed to prevent this.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20020506202442/http://www.buzzle.com/editorials/4-1-2002-15694.asp Mercy Killing Now Legal in Netherlands ]</ref>
===Switzerland=== {{Main|Euthanasia in Switzerland}}
Regulations were proposed to limit possibilities of legal suicide assistance for foreigners in Switzerland.<ref>Michael Leidig & Philip Sherwell, [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/expat/4191761/Swiss-to-crack-down-on-suicide-tourism.html "Swiss to crack down on suicide tourism,"] ''Telegraph'' (14 March 2004). Retrieved 4 May 2014.</ref> The law primarily targeted [[Dignitas (euthanasia group)|Dignitas]], one of two right-to-die groups in Switzerland assisting foreigners. The Swiss government rejected proposed stricter regulations in 2006, maintaining the ''status quo''<ref>[http://www.nzz.ch/2006/05/31/il/newzzENVLG88R-12.html Kein Gesetz gegen Sterbetourismus] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090720202604/http://www.nzz.ch/2006/05/31/il/newzzENVLG88R-12.html |date=2009-07-20 }} ''Neue Zürcher Zeitung''</ref> as regulated by Paragraph 115 of Swiss Criminal Code.
Although the assisted suicide market is largely German, as of August 2015, approximately 300 [[UK|British]] citizens had travelled to [[Switzerland]] from the [[UK]] to die at one of Dignitas' rented apartments in [[Zurich]]. <ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/society/2015/aug/15/assisted-dying-britons-dignitas-rises-campaigners-change-law | work=Guardian | title= ‘One person a fortnight’ travels to Dignitas from Britain to end their lives | date=August 15, 2015 | accessdate=August 17, 2015}}</ref> The names of a few of these people are known, though most remain anonymous.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/7697315.stm | work=BBC News | title=My brother chose to end his suffering | date=2008-10-29 | accessdate=2010-05-24}}</ref> By November 2008 the number of British members of Dignitas had risen to 725, a number exceeded only by Swiss and German membership.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/7732640.stm | work=BBC News | title=More Britons seeking suicide help | date=2008-11-17 | accessdate=2010-05-24}}</ref> Given the size and population density of [[Europe]], it is certain that there are Dignitas members in other European countries. Right-wing politicians in Switzerland have repeatedly criticized suicide assistance for foreigners, branding it ''suicide tourism'' (''Sterbetourismus'' in German).
In 2007, Dignitas launched an effort to gain legal permission for healthy foreigners, including married couples committed to suicide pacts, to end their lives in Switzerland.<ref>Jacob M. Appel, [http://www.huffingtonpost.com/jacob-m-appel/assisted-suicide-for-heal_b_236664.html "Next: Assisted Suicide for Healthy People,"] ''The Huffington Post'' (16 July 2009). Retrieved 4 May 2014.</ref>
In July 2009, British conductor [[Sir Edward Downes]] and his wife Joan died together at a suicide clinic outside Zürich "under circumstances of their own choosing." Sir Edward was not terminally ill, but his wife was diagnosed with rapidly developing cancer.<ref name="CB1">{{cite web|url=http://criminalbrief.com/?p=7887| title=YOUthanasia| last=Lundin|first=Leigh |date=2009-08-02| publisher=Criminal Brief| accessdate=2009-08-27}}</ref>
In March 2010, the PBS [[List of Frontline (PBS) episodes|Frontline]] TV program in the United States showed a documentary called "The Suicide Tourist" which told the story of Professor Craig Ewert, his family, and Dignitas, and their decision to commit assisted suicide in Switzerland after he was diagnosed and suffering with [[Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis|ALS]] (Lou Gehrig's Disease).<ref>[https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/suicidetourist/ "The Suicide Tourist"], PBS Frontline, March 2, 2010.</ref>
In a [[referendum]] on 15 May 2011, voters in the [[Canton of Zurich]] have overwhelmingly rejected calls to ban assisted suicide or to outlaw the practice for non-residents. Out of more than 278,000 ballots cast, the initiative to ban assisted suicide was rejected by 85% of voters and the initiative to outlaw it for foreigners was turned down by 78%.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/switzerland/8515258/Zurich-votes-to-keep-suicide-tourism-alive.html | location=London | work=The Daily Telegraph | title=Zurich votes to keep 'suicide tourism' alive | date=2011-05-15}}</ref><ref>[http://www.cbsnews.com/news/zurich-voters-keep-suicide-tourism-alive/ "Zurich voters keep "suicide tourism" alive,"] ''CBS News'' (15 May 2011). Retrieved 4 May 2014.</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2011/05/15/zurich-voters-suicide-tourism-alive/ | work=Fox News | title=Zurich voters keep 'suicide tourism' alive | date=2011-05-15}}</ref>
===United Kingdom=== {{Main|Euthanasia in the United Kingdom}} In 2009, the British Parliament said it would consider an amendment to a bill that would allow suicide tourism by not charging people with assisting suicide when they take their loved ones to another nation to kill themselves. Britain has a law banning assisted suicide, but it hasn't been enforced in those cases.<ref>Steven Ertelt, [http://www.lifenews.com/bio2802.html "British Parliament to Consider OKing Suicide Tourism, Pro-Life Groups Opposed,"] ''LifeNews.com'' (20 March 2009). Retrieved 4 May 2014.</ref>
===United States=== {{Main|Euthanasia in the United States}} In 1997, the Oregon Death with Dignity Act went into effect.<ref name="deathwithdignity.org">{{cite web|url=http://www.deathwithdignity.org/access-acts|title=Death with Dignity: the Laws & How to Access Them|publisher=|accessdate=8 October 2015}}</ref> In 2008, Washington state passed their law which was then implemented in 2009.<ref name="deathwithdignity.org"/> Laws may only be implemented by licensed physicians based on the individual needs of qualified patients. Patients must meet state requirements to be eligible for euthanasia.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.compassionandchoices.org/what-you-can-do/in-your-state/oregon/?a=home|title=Oregon|publisher=|accessdate=8 October 2015}}{{Dead link|date=June 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=no }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://compassionwa.org/|title=Home - Compassion & Choices of Washington|author=Compassion & Choices of Washington|work=Compassion & Choices of Washington|accessdate=8 October 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101204084221/http://www.compassionwa.org/|archivedate=4 December 2010|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vtethicsnetwork.org/pad.html|title=Vermont Ethics Network|publisher=|accessdate=8 October 2015}}</ref>
==See also== {{Portal|Death}} *[[List of suicide sites]]
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20120923155038/http://www.lifecircle.ch/en/ lifecircle] *[http://dignitas.ch/index.php?lang=en Dignitas] *[http://dignitas.ch/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=23&Itemid=84&lang=en Brochure "How DIGNITAS works"] *"[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/jacob-m-appel/assisted-suicide-for-heal_b_236664.html Next: Assisted Suicide for Healthy People]". [[Huffington Post]]
{{tourism}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2018}} {{Use Australian English|date=June 2011}} {{Infobox person | name = The Somerton Man | image = SomertonMan2.jpg | caption = Police photo of the corpse, 1948 | birth_name = | birth_date = | birth_place = | death_date = {{death date|df=yes|1948|12|1}} | death_place = [[Somerton, South Australia]] | resting_place = [[West Terrace Cemetery]], Adelaide, South Australia | resting_place_coordinates = Gravesite: P3, 12, 106 | other_names = [[John Doe|Unknown Man]] (police terminology), Somerton Man | known_for = Mysterious death | education = | employer = | relatives = | signature = | website = | footnotes = }} The '''Tamam Shud case''', also known as the '''Mystery of the Somerton Man''', is an [[Cold case (criminology)|unsolved case]] of an unidentified man found dead at 6:30 am, 1 December 1948, on [[Somerton Park, South Australia|Somerton]] beach, [[Glenelg, South Australia|Glenelg]], just south of [[Adelaide]], [[South Australia]]. It is named after the [[Persian language|Persian]] phrase ''tamám shud'', meaning "ended" or "finished", printed on a scrap of paper found months later in the [[Besom pocket|fob pocket]] of the man's trousers. The scrap had been torn from the final page of a copy of ''[[Rubaiyat of Omar Khayyam]]'', authored by 12th-century poet [[Omar Khayyám]]. ''Tamam'' was misspelt as ''Taman'' in many early reports and this error has often been repeated, leading to confusion about the name in the media.{{refn|group="note"|While the words that end ''[[The Rubaiyat]]'' are "Tamám Shud" ({{lang|fa|تمام شد}}), it has often been referred to as "Taman Shud" in the media, because of a spelling error in early newspaper coverage or police reports which has persisted.{{citation needed|date=June 2016}} In [[Persian language|Persian]], {{lang|fa|[[wikt:تمام#Persian|تمام]]}} ''tamám'' is a noun that means "the end" and {{lang|fa|[[wikt:شد#Persian|شد]]}} ''shud'' is an auxiliary verb indicating past tense, so ''tamam shud'' means "ended" or "finished".{{cite web |last1=Abbott |first1=Derek |title=List of facts on the Taman Shud Case that are often misreported |url=https://www.eleceng.adelaide.edu.au/personal/dabbott/wiki/index.php/List_of_facts_on_the_Taman_Shud_Case_that_are_often_misreported |accessdate=19 November 2018}}}} Following a public appeal by police, the book from which the page had been torn was located. On the inside back cover, detectives were able to read – in indentations from handwriting – a local telephone number, another unidentified number and a text that resembled an encrypted message. The text has not been deciphered or interpreted in a way that satisfies authorities on the case. The case has been considered, since the early stages of the police investigation, "one of Australia's most profound mysteries".''The Advertiser'', [http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article36371416 "Tamam Shud"], 10 June 1949, p. 2 There has been intense speculation ever since regarding the identity of the victim, the cause of his death and the events leading up to it. Public interest in the case remains significant for several reasons: the death occurred at a time of heightened international tensions following the beginning of the [[Cold War]]; the apparent involvement of a secret code; the possible use of an undetectable poison; and the inability of authorities to identify the dead man. In addition to intense public interest in Australia during the late 1940s and early 1950s, the Tamam Shud case also attracted international attention. [[South Australian Police]] consulted their counterparts overseas and distributed information about the dead man internationally, in an effort to identify him.See, for example; Guðmundsson, H.H. "Þekkir þú þennan mann?" ''Skakki turninn'', 12 October 2009, pp. 19–27. International circulation of a photograph of the man and details of his fingerprints yielded no positive identification. For example, in the United States, the [[FBI]] was unable to match the dead man's fingerprint with prints taken from files of domestic criminals. [[Scotland Yard]] was also asked to assist with the case, but could not offer any insights. In recent years new evidence has emerged, including an old identification card possibly identifying the Somerton Man as one H. C. ReynoldsEmily Watkins: [http://www.adelaidenow.com.au/news/is-british-seamans-identity-card-clue-to-solving-63-year-old-beach-body-mystery/news-story/b0f696e3e2a3d82a88cb5d1788f17f25 Is British seaman's identity card clue to solving 63-year-old beach body mystery?], 19 November 2011 and an ongoing DNA analysis of hair roots found on the plaster bust. Jessica Bineth: "[http://www.abc.net.au/news/2017-12-14/somerton-man-cold-case-could-be-one-step-closer-to-solved/9245512 Somerton Man: One of Australia's most baffling cold cases could be a step closer to being solved]", ABC News, 2 January 2018 ==Discovery of body== [[File:SomertonManDeathSite.jpg|thumb|Location on [[Somerton Park, South Australia|Somerton]] beach where the corpse was found, marked by an 'X']] On 1 December 1948 at 6:30 am, the police were contacted after the body of a man was discovered on Somerton beach near Glenelg, about 11 kilometres (6.8 mi) southwest of Adelaide, South Australia. The man was found lying in the sand across from the Crippled Children's Home, which was on the corner of The Esplanade and Bickford Terrace.{{cite news|url=http://blogs.smithsonianmag.com/history/2011/08/the-body-on-somerton-beach/|title=The Body on Somerton Beach|first=Mike|last=Dash|work=[[Smithsonian (magazine)|Smithsonian]]|date=12 August 2011|accessdate=18 July 2015}} He was lying back with his head resting against the [[seawall]], with his legs extended and his feet crossed. It was believed he had died while sleeping. An unlit cigarette was on the right collar of his coat. A search of his pockets revealed an unused second-class rail ticket from Adelaide to [[Henley Beach, South Australia|Henley Beach]], a bus ticket from the city that could not be proved to have been used, a narrow aluminium American comb, a half-empty packet of [[Juicy Fruit]] chewing gum, an [[Army Club (cigarette)|Army Club]] cigarette packet containing seven cigarettes of a different brand, and a quarter-full box of [[Bryant and May|Bryant & May matches]]. Witnesses who came forward said that on the evening of 30 November, they had seen an individual resembling the dead man lying on his back in the same spot and position near the Crippled Children's Home where the corpse was later found.{{cite web|title=Top 10 Secrets Taken to the Grave|url=http://www.mixtopten.com/top-10-secrets-taken-to-the-grave/|accessdate=1 December 2014}} A couple who saw him at around 7 pm noted that they saw him extend his right arm to its fullest extent and then drop it limply. Another couple who saw him from 7:30 pm to 8 pm, during which time the street lights had come on, recounted that they did not see him move during the half an hour in which he was in view, although they did have the impression that his position had changed. Although they commented between themselves that he must be dead because he was not reacting to the mosquitoes, they had thought it more likely that he was drunk or asleep, and thus did not investigate further. One of the witnesses told the police she observed a man looking down at the sleeping man from the top of the steps that lead to the beach.Clemo, M. "[http://www.eleceng.adelaide.edu.au/personal/dabbott/tamanshud/sunday_mail_nov2004.pdf 'Poisoned' in SA – was he a Red Spy?]", ''Sunday Mail'' (Adelaide), 7 November 2004, p 76.{{sfnp|Cleland|1949|p=9}} Witnesses said the body was in the same position when the police viewed it.{{sfnp|Cleland|1949|p=2}} Another witness came forward in 1959 and reported to the police that he and three others had seen a well-dressed man carrying another man on his shoulders along Somerton Beach the night before the body was found. A police report was made by Detective Don O'Doherty.{{sfnp|Feltus|2010}} According to the pathologist, [[John Burton Cleland]], the man was of "Britisher" appearance and thought to be aged about 40–45; he was in "top physical condition".{{sfnp|Cleland|1949|pp=12–13}} He was "180 centimetres (5 ft 11 in) tall, with grey eyes, fair to ginger-coloured hair, slightly grey around the temples, with broad shoulders and a narrow waist, hands and nails that showed no signs of manual labour, big and little toes that met in a wedge shape, like those of a dancer or someone who wore boots with pointed toes; and pronounced high calf muscles consistent with people who regularly wore boots or shoes with high heels or performed ballet.Fife-Yeomans, J. "The Man With No Name", ''The Weekend Australian Magazine'', 15-16 September 2001, p 30 He was dressed in a white shirt; a red, white and blue tie; brown trousers; socks and shoes; a brown knitted pullover and fashionable grey and brown double-breasted jacket of reportedly "American" tailoring.Jory, R. (2000) "[http://www.eleceng.adelaide.edu.au/personal/dabbott/tamanshud/advertiser_dec2000.pdf The dead man who sparked many tales]", ''The Advertiser'', 1 December 2000. All labels on his clothes had been removed,{{cite web|url=http://sometimes-interesting.com/2011/06/25/the-somerton-man-the-taman-shud-case/|title=Unsolved Death from 1948: The Somerton Man (The Taman Shud Case)|website=Sometimes Interesting|date=25 June 2011|access-date=28 July 2015}} and he had no hat (unusual for 1948) or wallet. The body was clean-shaven and''The News'', "[http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article129897161 Dead Man Found Lying on Somerton Beach]", 1 December 1948, p. 1 carried no identification, which led police to believe he had committed suicide.''The News'', "[http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article130240390 Five 'positive views' conflict]", 7 January 1949, p. 3 His teeth did not match the dental records of any known living person.{{cite news|last=Britten|first=Nick|title=Top 10 uncracked codes|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/howaboutthat/8293375/Top-10-uncracked-codes.html|accessdate=10 January 2014|date=1 February 2011|newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|quote=There were no clues as to his identity and dental records and fingerprints matched no living person.}} Coroner Cleland remarked that if the body had been carried to its final resting place then "all the difficulties would disappear".{{sfnp|Feltus|2010}} An autopsy was conducted, and the pathologist estimated the time of death at around 2 a.m. on 1 December.{{sfnp|Cleland|1949|pp=12–13}}
The heart was of normal size, and normal in every way ...small vessels not commonly observed in the brain were easily discernible with congestion. There was congestion of the [[pharynx]], and the [[gullet]] was covered with whitening of superficial layers of the [[mucosa]] with a patch of [[ulceration]] in the middle of it. The stomach was deeply congested... There was congestion in the second half of the [[duodenum]]. There was blood mixed with the food in the stomach. Both kidneys were congested, and the liver contained a great excess of blood in its vessels. ...The spleen was strikingly large ... about 3 times normal size ... there was destruction of the centre of the liver [[lobules]] revealed under the microscope. ... acute [[gastritis]] hemorrhage, extensive congestion of the liver and spleen, and the congestion to the brain.
The autopsy showed that the man's last meal was a [[pasty]] eaten three to four hours before death, but tests failed to reveal any foreign substance in the body. The pathologist Dr. Dwyer concluded: "I am quite convinced the death could not have been natural ... the poison I suggested was a [[barbiturate]] or a soluble [[hypnotic]]". Although poisoning remained a prime suspicion, the pasty was not believed to be the source of the poison. Other than that, the coroner was unable to reach a conclusion as to the man's identity, cause of death, or whether the man seen alive at Somerton Beach on the evening of 30 November was the same man, as nobody had seen his face at that time. The body was then [[Embalming|embalmed]] on 10 December 1948 after the police were unable to get a positive identification. The police said this was the first time they knew that such action was needed.''The Advertiser'', "[http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article43795238 Somerton Body Embalmed]", 11 December 1948, p. 2 ==Discovery of suitcase== [[File:SomertonManSuitcase.jpg|thumb|170px|right|Suitcase and effects, found at [[Adelaide railway station]]. From left to right are detectives Dave Bartlett, Lionel Leane, and Len Brown]] On 14 January 1949, staff at the [[Adelaide railway station]] discovered a brown suitcase with its label removed, which had been checked into the station cloakroom after 11:00 a.m. on 30 November 1948.''The Advertiser'', "[http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article43800028 Somerton Mystery Clue]", 15 January 1949, p.1 It was believed that the suitcase was owned by the man found on the beach. In the case were a red checked dressing gown; a size-seven, red felt pair of slippers; four pairs of underpants; pyjamas; shaving items; a light brown pair of trousers with sand in the [[cuff]]s; an electrician's screwdriver; a table knife cut down into a short sharp instrument; a pair of scissors with sharpened points; a small square of zinc thought to have been used as a protective sheath for the knife and scissors and a [[stencil]]ling brush, as used by [[Third mate|third officers]] on merchant ships for stencilling cargo.''The Advertiser'', "[http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article43800320 Definite Clue in Somerton Mystery]", 18 January 1949, p.1 Also in the suitcase was a thread card of [[J. Barbour and Sons|Barbour]] brand orange waxed thread of "an unusual type" not available in Australia—it was the same as that used to repair the lining in a pocket of the trousers the dead man was wearing. All identification marks on the clothes had been removed but police found the name "T. Keane" on a tie, "Keane" on a laundry bag and "Kean" (without the last e) on a [[Vest|singlet]], along with three dry-cleaning marks; 1171/7, 4393/7 and 3053/7.''The News'', "[http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article130244472 Marks May Be Clue To Beach Body]", 15 January 1949, p. 8''The Mail'', "[http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article55926571 Cotton May Be Clue To Mystery]", 15 January 1949, p. 6 Police believed that whoever removed the clothing tags either overlooked these three items or purposely left the "Keane" tags on the clothes, knowing Keane was not the dead man's name. With wartime rationing still enforced, clothing was difficult to acquire at that time. Although it was a very common practice to use name tags, it was also common when buying secondhand clothing to remove the tags of the previous owner/s. What was unusual was that there were no spare socks found in the case, and no correspondence, despite that the police found pencils and unused letter [[stationery]]. A search concluded that there was no T. Keane missing in any English-speaking country and a nationwide circulation of the dry-cleaning marks also proved fruitless. In fact, all that could be garnered from the suitcase was that the front [[gusset]] and [[featherstitch]]ing on a coat found in the case indicated it had been manufactured in the United States. The coat had not been imported, indicating the man had been to the United States or bought the coat from someone of similar size who had been.{{sfnp|Cleland|1949|p=23}} Police checked incoming train records and believed the man had arrived at the [[Adelaide railway station]] by overnight train from either Melbourne, Sydney or [[Port Augusta, South Australia|Port Augusta]]. They speculated he had showered and shaved at the adjacent City Baths (there was no Baths ticket on his body) before returning to the train station to purchase a ticket for the 10:50 a.m. train to Henley Beach, which, for whatever reason, he missed or did not catch. He immediately checked his suitcase at the station cloak room before leaving the station and catching a city bus to Glenelg.''The News'', "[http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article130240390 Five 'Positive' Views Conflict]", 7 January 1949, p. 12 Although named the City Baths, the centre was not a [[public bathing]] facility but a public swimming pool. The railway station bathing facilities were adjacent to the station cloak room, which itself was adjacent to the station's southern exit onto North Terrace. The City Baths on [[King William Street, Adelaide|King William St.]] were accessed from the station's northern exit via a lane way.{{cite web|last=Fettes|first=James|url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/news/law-order/portrait-may-hold-key-to-somerton-man-beach-mystery/story-fni0ffnk-1226674957043|title=Professor's 15-year search for answers seeks to crack the secret code to the death of the 'Somerton man' found on an Adelaide beach |work=[[Herald Sun]]|date=29 October 2013|accessdate=27 June 2015}}{{cite web|author=James Fettes |url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/news/law-order/portrait-may-hold-key-to-somerton-man-beach-mystery/story-fni0ffnk-1226674957043 |title=Professor's 15-year search for answers seeks to crack the secret code to the death of the 'Somerton man' found on an Adelaide beach |publisher=HeraldSun |date=29 October 2013 |accessdate=30 June 2017}} There is no record of the station's bathroom facilities being unavailable on the day he arrived. ==Inquest== An inquest into the death, conducted by coroner Thomas Erskine Cleland, commenced a few days after the body was found but was adjourned until 17 June 1949.{{cite web |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article2809097 |title=15 Jun 1949 – INQUEST TO OPEN ON BODY OF UNKNOWN MAN – ADELAIDE |work=[[The Canberra Times]] |via=[[Trove]] |access-date=27 June 2015 |date=15 June 1949}} The investigating pathologist [[John Burton Cleland]] re-examined the body and made a number of discoveries. Cleland noted that the man's shoes were remarkably clean and appeared to have been recently polished, rather than being in the state expected of the shoes of a man who had apparently been wandering around Glenelg all day. He added that this evidence fitted in with the theory that the body might have been brought to Somerton beach after the man's death, accounting for the lack of evidence of vomiting and convulsions, which are the two main effects of poison. Thomas Cleland speculated that as none of the witnesses could positively identify the man they saw the previous night as being the same person discovered the next morning, there remained the possibility the man had died elsewhere and had been dumped. He stressed that this was purely speculation as all the witnesses believed it was "definitely the same person" as the body was in the same place and lying in the same distinctive position. He also found there was no evidence as to who the deceased was.{{sfnp|Cleland|1949|pp=1–3}} [[Cedric Stanton Hicks]], Professor of [[physiology]] and [[pharmacology]] at the University of Adelaide, testified that of a group of drugs, variants of a drug in that group he called "number 1" and in particular "number 2" were extremely toxic in a relatively small oral dose that would be extremely difficult if not impossible to identify even if it had been suspected in the first instance. He gave the coroner a piece of paper with the names of the two drugs which was entered as Exhibit C.18. The names were not released to the public until the 1980s as at the time they were "quite easily procurable by the ordinary individual" from a [[Pharmacy|chemist]] without the need to give a reason for the purchase. (The drugs were later publicly identified as [[digitalis]] and [[ouabain]], both of which are [[cardenolide]]-type [[cardiac glycoside]]s). He noted the only "fact" not found in relation to the body was evidence of vomiting. He then stated its absence was not unknown but that he could not make a "frank conclusion" without it. Hicks stated that if death had occurred seven hours after the man was last seen to move, it would imply a massive dose that could still have been undetectable. It was noted that the movement seen by witnesses at 7 p.m. could have been the last convulsion preceding death.{{sfnp|Cleland|1949|pp=42–44}} Early in the inquiry, Cleland stated "I would be prepared to find that he died from poison, that the poison was probably a [[glucoside]] and that it was not accidentally administered; but I cannot say whether it was administered by the deceased himself or by some other person."{{sfnp|Cleland|1949|pp=1–3}} Despite these findings, he could not determine the cause of death of the Somerton Man,''The Advertiser'', "[http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article36677396 Possible Clue in Somerton Body Case]", 23 July 1949, p. 1 and after the inquest, a plaster cast was made of the man's head and shoulders. The lack of success in determining the identity and cause of death of the Somerton Man had led authorities to call it an "unparalleled mystery" and believe that the cause of death might never be known.''The Advertiser'', "[http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article36361680 'Unparalleled Mystery' Of Somerton Body Case]", 11 April 1949 ==Connection to the ''Rubaiyat of Omar Khayyam''== [[File:Actual-tamam-shud.jpg|thumb|The scrap of paper, with its distinctive font, found hidden in the dead man's trousers, torn from the last page of a rare New Zealand edition of ''The Rubaiyat of Omar Khayyam'']] Around the same time as the inquest, a tiny piece of rolled-up paper with the words "Tamam Shud" printed on it was found in a fob pocket sewn within the dead man's trouser pocket.''The Advertiser'', "[http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article36371152 Cryptic Note on Body]", 9 June 1949, p. 1 Public library officials called in to translate the text identified it as a phrase meaning "ended" or "finished" found on the last page of the ''[[Rubaiyat of Omar Khayyam]]''. The paper's [[recto and verso|verso]] side was blank. Police conducted an Australia-wide search to find a copy of the book that had a similarly blank verso. A photograph of the scrap of paper was released to the press. Following a public appeal by police, the copy of the ''Rubaiyat'' from which the page had been torn was located. A man showed police a 1941 edition of [[Edward FitzGerald (poet)|Edward FitzGerald's]] (1859) translation of the ''Rubaiyat'', published by [[Whitcoulls|Whitcombe and Tombs]] in [[Christchurch]], New Zealand.{{refn|group="note"|This particular edition of the ''Rubaiyat'' has a different translation compared to most other FitzGerald translations. This, now rare, edition was published in New Zealand in 1941.{{cite news |title=New Zealand Book News |url=https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/AS19411122.2.105.3?end_date=22-11-1941&query=Book+news&start_date=22-11-1941&title=AS |work=Aukland Star |date=22 November 1941 |page=12 |language=en}}}} [[Detective Sergeant]] Lionel Leane, who led the initial investigation, often protected the privacy of witnesses in public statements by using [[pseudonym]]s;{{sfnp|Feltus|2010}} Leane referred to the man who found the book by the pseudonym "Ronald Francis" and he has never been officially identified.{{sfnp|Feltus|2010}} "Francis" had not considered that the book might be connected to the case until he had seen an article in the previous day's newspaper. On the inside back cover of the book, detectives identified indentations from handwriting. These included a telephone number, an unidentified number, and a text that resembled an encrypted message. According to statements by police, the book was found in the rear footwell of a car, at about the same time that the body of the unidentified man had been found. There is some uncertainty about the circumstances under which the book was found. One newspaper article refers to the book being found about a week or two before the body was found.''The Advertiser'', "[http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article36677719 New Clue in Somerton Body Mystery]", 25 July 1949, p. 3 Former South Australian Police detective Gerry Feltus (who dealt with the matter as a cold case), reports that the book was found "just after that man was found on the beach at Somerton".{{sfnp|Feltus|2010|p=105}} The timing is significant as the man is presumed, based on the suitcase, to have arrived in Adelaide the day before he was found on the beach. If the book was found one or two weeks before, it suggests that the man had visited previously or had been in Adelaide for a longer period. Most accounts state that the book was found in an unlocked car parked in Jetty Road, [[Glenelg, South Australia|Glenelg]] – either in the rear floor well, or on the back seat.{{refn|group=note|However, a bus conductor named Leslie Francis Wytkin (or Wytkins) handed in a copy of the ''Rubaiyat'' to the Metropolitan Tramways Trust, at around the same time; it is not clear whether this was the same copy of the ''Rubaiyat'', or an extraneous find, and/or if Wytkin was "Francis".{{cite news |title=Possible Clue In Somerton Body Case |url=https://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/36677396/2653957 |work=The Advertiser |date=23 July 1949 |pages=1}}}} [[File:SomertonManCode.jpg|thumb|right|The handwriting found in the back of a book of the [[Rubáiyát of Omar Khayyám]]. The text is presumed to be some sort of code.]] The theme of the ''Rubaiyat of Omar Khayyam'' is that one should live life to the fullest and have no regrets when it ends. The poem's subject led police to theorise that the man had committed suicide by poison, although there was no other evidence to back the theory. The book was missing the words "Tamám Shud" on the last page, which had a blank reverse, and microscopic tests indicated that the piece of paper was from the page torn from the book.''The Advertiser'', "[http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article36677872 Police Test Book For Somerton Body Clue]", 26 July 1949, p. 3 Also, In the back of the book were faint indentations representing five lines of text, in capital letters. The second line has been struck out – a fact that is considered significant, due to its similarities to the fourth line and the possibility that it represents an error in encryption.
WRGOABABD MLIAOI WTBIMPANETP MLIABOAIAQC ITTMTSAMSTGABMaguire, S. "[http://www.eleceng.adelaide.edu.au/personal/dabbott/tamanshud/advertiser_mar2005.pdf Death riddle of a man with no name]", ''The Advertiser'', 9 March 2005, p. 28
In the book it is unclear whether the first line begins with an "M" or "W", but it is widely believed to be the letter W, owing to the distinctive difference when compared to the stricken letter M. There appears to be a deleted or underlined line of text that reads "MLIAOI". Although the last character in this line of text looks like an "L", it is fairly clear on closer inspection of the image that this is formed from an 'I' and the extension of the line used to delete or underline that line of text. Also, the other "L" has a curve to the bottom part of the character. There is also an "X" above the last 'O' in the code, and it is not known if this is significant to the code or not. Initially, the letters were thought to be words in a foreign language before it was realised it was a code. Code experts were called in at the time to decipher the lines but were unsuccessful. In 1978, following a request from ABC-TV journalist [[Stuart Littlemore]], [[Australian Department of Defence|Department of Defence]] cryptographers analysed the handwritten text. The cryptographers reported that it would be impossible to provide "a satisfactory answer": if the text was an encrypted message, its brevity meant that it had "insufficient symbols", from which a clear meaning could be extracted, and the text could be the "meaningless" product of a "disturbed mind".''Inside Story'', presented by Stuart Littlemore, ABC TV, screened at 8 pm, Thursday, 24 August 1978. An unlisted telephone number was also found in the back of the book, belonging to a nurse named Jessica Ellen "Jo" Thomson (1921–2007) – born Jessie Harkness in the Sydney suburb of [[Marrickville]] – who lived in Moseley St, [[Glenelg, South Australia|Glenelg]], about {{convert|400|m|ft}} north of the location where the body was found.{{cite news | newspaper=The Canberra Times | url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article2815851 | title=No Sydney Clue to Dead Man Found at Somerton, S.A. | date=28 July 1949}} When she was interviewed by police, Thomson said that she did not know the dead man or why he would have her phone number and choose to visit her suburb on the night of his death. However, she also reported that, at some time in late 1948, an unidentified man had attempted to visit her and asked a next door neighbour about her. In his book on the case, Gerry Feltus stated that when he interviewed Thomson (2002), he found that she was either being "evasive" or she "just did not wish to talk about it". Feltus believed Thomson knew the Somerton man's identity.{{sfnp|Feltus|2010|pp=178–179}} Thomson's daughter Kate, in a television interview (2014) with ''[[60 Minutes (Australian TV program)|60 Minutes]]'', also said that she believed her mother knew the dead man. In 1949, Jessica Thomson requested that police not keep a permanent record of her name or release her details to third parties, as it would be embarrassing and harmful to her reputation to be linked to such a case. The police agreed – a decision that hampered later investigations. In news media, books and other discussions of the case, Thomson was frequently referred to by various pseudonyms, including the nickname "Jestyn" and names such as "Teresa Johnson [[née]] Powell". Gerry Feltus (2010) claimed he was given permission by Thomson's family to disclose her names and that of her husband, Prosper Thomson.{{sfnp|Feltus|2010|pp=178–179}} Nevertheless, the names Feltus used in his book were pseudonyms. Feltus also stated that her family did not know of her connection with the case, and he agreed not to disclose her identity or anything that might reveal it. Her real name was considered important as the possibility exists that it may be the [[Key (cryptography)|decryption key]] for the purported code. When she was shown the plaster cast bust of the dead man by Detective Sergeant Leane, Thomson said she could not identify the person depicted.Lewes, J.
